div.p: The Association for Diplomatic Studies and Training Foreign Affairs Oral History Project
GILIAN JACOT GUILLARMOD
Interviewed by: Daniel F. Whitman
Initial interview date: March 5, 2009
Copyright 2011 ADST

p.hi: Q: Okay, here we are. This is Dan Whitman at the University of Pretoria. This is the 5th of March, 2009, and we're going to talk to Gill Jacot Guillarmod. And what we should do first, Gill, because there's a transcriber involved here, could you spell your name?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Sure. It's G-I-L-L; that's actually an abbreviation, my official name is G-I-L-I-A-N, and my surname is long, J-A-C-O-T, new word, G-U-I-L-L-A-R-M-O-D.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Thanks, Gill.

div.p: Now, when you were working at the U.S. embassy at Pretoria, you had spent several decades working on cultural exchanges and other types of things. I'd like to ask you first, where were you born?
JACOT GUILLARMOD: I was born in Cape Town in 1942, and I joined the embassy there in 1964. And I was there for five years until I left to come to Pretoria to be married.

p.hi: Q: Now, you say embassy; in those days it-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: It was USIS (United States Information Service).

p.hi: Q: -the embassy used to go back and forth, I believe, from Pretoria to Cape Town, depending on whether Parliament was in session.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes but we had an American consulate general and I was with the little- tiny little USIS office.

p.hi: Q: Tiny little USIS office within the consulate.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Now, going back, sorry, you said '64?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Sixty-four to '69.

p.hi: Q: When we think of when this started really changing in the '90s, this was 30 years before. So tell me what you can remember of the things that you did during those five years and what was it like in Cape Town at that time, with the- Well, the previous system, as it was.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Well, it was horrible. I mean, it was better, I have to say when I joined there I really wasn't aware of quite how horrible it was. My being with the embassy affected by outlook on life and I had the great privilege of being- I was a Gill of all trades because we had a librarian and then there was Gill, and I did the press placement and I did the film library. I used to take movies into the townships in the big old station wagon and screen films.

p.hi: Q: Sixteen millimeter?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Sixteen millimeter.

p.hi: Q: The old threading the machine and all that?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And the sprockets would break and have to stick- And the most popular, there were two movies that were really population, “The Golden Age of Comedy” and the other one was “Years of Lightening, Day of Drums,” but I always took along our propaganda as well in the hope that they would- the audience would enjoy that too.

p.hi: Q: Now, when you mention townships, I know there were restrictions.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. I went usually to Guguletu.

p.hi: Q: Guguletu. Were there restrictions on the people classified as whites in going into the townships?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes but I was in a dip car and I never, ever had a problem.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Were you usually accompanied by an American diplomat when you went? Sometimes yes, sometimes no?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Usually no.

p.hi: Q: Usually no, okay. Now, was this a given already in 1964 that 16 millimeter films- What were the tools of the trade back then? Films, press releases?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: The library. Oh, and a lot of press, a great deal press. We used to get all those, you might remember from IPS (Inter Press Service) thousands of photographs, all these photographs and multiple copies of them, many of them with no captions on the photo.

p.hi: Q: From the photo archives from Washington.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. And then everything about, or desalinization and the Hoover Dam and just all sorts of things to tell America's story to the world.

p.hi: Q: And what were you able to do with these materials?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: With the press I used to- When I worked for a new BPAO (Branch Public Affairs Officer), David Michael Wilson, David- you know David- and David decided I was young and blonde and mini skirted in those days that just sending the things in the mail would just- the press stuff would all just land up in some news editor's in drop box and not get used. I used to take the things up to- go up to the “Burger” and the “Argus” and the “Cape Times” and then get to meet people.

p.hi: Q: The local papers.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And it- it definitely did improve placement. I'm not saying that was because I was young and blonde; I think it was the personal, you know, actually handing it over to somebody.

p.hi: Q: And so you worked with David on this, with his encouragement you went and you made frequent- you actually-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I used to go once or twice a week up to the three main newspapers.

p.hi: Q: Three; “Argus,” “Burger,” and then another one.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: “Times.”

p.hi: Q: The “Times,” okay. So this was purely a Cape Town activity?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes.

p.hi: Q: Although Cape Town had its importance as the parliament-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Of course, yes.

p.hi: Q: and at that time- it was parliament, basically, yes. Now, parliament was in session, I think half a year?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: From January to June; end of January to June.

p.hi: Q: And what used to happen from June to January then? You were still there, you were-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Would things slow down a bit?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I can't even think that it was quiet, actually, because I think we always were doing things with education, with University of Cape Town; NUCES, the student body was- we were very active and we tried to work with them quite a lot. And with the- in those days there was that big high building behind us, the South African Information Service was there and the BPAOs would make a point of mixing and establishing relationships with the officials from South African Information Service.

p.hi: Q: So even back then it was- was it a tempered thing of trying to be in touch and in contact with all strata of society?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, we made a concert- We liked to lay claim to the fact that we provided the first opportunity for a little black theatrical group to perform, and they did a play and I can't now remember the name of it, but they brought into our funny little library that we had and we had a play with a mixed- they were from Guguletu. There was a man there by the name of Ben [Office.]

p.hi: Q: Whose idea was this?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: The BPAOs usually.

p.hi: Q: The BPAO. Just David-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: It was David, it was Clark Thornton, Tom Gunning; those were the three.

p.hi: Q: Oh, so you had a team of three?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, no, no, they were successive ones.

p.hi: Q: I see.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I was the secretary to the BPAO so I did, you know, I would do the filing and the secretarial work.

p.hi: Q: The Gill of all trades.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Now, you said-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Used to get the Wireless File in those days. I used to say oh God, I'm going to get embalmed; when I die they'll bury me and wrap this around me.

p.hi: Q: It was paper at that time that came; it was sort of a telex.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Lots of trees; lots of trees. Yes, it was a telex, it was a telex. We sent messages by telex and I had a-

p.hi: Q: We almost have to explain to young readers what a telex was because I'm not sure they have them anymore.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Oh yes, certainly.

p.hi: Q: It was like a telegram but it was a little bit more-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: It's like in the old movies, if you look at that.

p.hi: Q: Tick, tick, tick, tick.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Tick, tick, yes.

p.hi: Q: The ticker machine, yes. It would come overnight; you would actually find it in paper form in the morning.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Clip it up and- no photocopiers at that time.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No. Well, there was a photocopier but you did what they called to burn a copy, and you put this piece of paper with- you put another piece of sort of shiny kind of paper over it, and bear in mind I'm technically challenged, so I can't-

p.hi: Q: As I am, for the record.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And you would feed the piece of paper with the other copy into this machine, it would go over rollers and then come out on this paper, shiny paper, which eventually then, didn't last for a year, even, I don't think. It would just fade. But you had the copy when you wanted it.

p.hi: Q: I've seen those; it was not so different from the mimeograph machine.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And we used to do that also. If we did a newsletter then you would type that up.

p.hi: Q: And the type was not so good, it smudged something like that.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And it made holes in the paper.

p.hi: Q: I guess we could note for future generations that this is the origin of the word “burn,” because they burn a CD, right.

div.p: Now, at the beginning Gill, you were saying that it was horrible. In what way and when did you find out about this?
JACOT GUILLARMOD: Well, it was just that- it was just because black people were denied everything.

p.hi: Q: You said at the beginning this was something you were not aware of. I understand that the system separated-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, I think I was just blind.

p.hi: Q: -and didn't make things visible.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: In your work with the U.S. consulate how did this become apparent to you?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I think just for the first time the people that I encountered, that I would serve in the library when I was there or who would come in for an appointment, come in to ask questions also, would be black people. Before that all the black people I had met had all had menial jobs. They worked in the streets or in people's homes and I then got to realize wow, you know.

p.hi: Q: Yes. What were the possibilities in the '60s for a black person, I suppose we should talk about colored, Indian and the others as well.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Don't forget there weren't a hell of a lot of black Africans in Cape Town in those days. There was Guguletu-

p.hi: Q: They were in the Cape but not in the city?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes.

p.hi: Q: So but you did get a trickle of people in the central business district.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: What type of person, what type of black person did you get?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Educators and church people.

p.hi: Q: So they knew in the beginning that they were welcome in the Center?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Yes, yes.

div.p: When had the library been created? In the '40s, in the '50s, in the '60s? Any idea? It was there when you arrived.

JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, I can't. It was there when I arrived. It was in Monte Carlo building. The consulate general was in Broadway building and Monte Carlo building was adjoining; there was a big door that separated us. But I used to- and I'd go to work, I would come in through the Monte Carlo entrance.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Not to be obsessive about the race thing but I believe there were four categories.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: White, Asian, Coloured, and African.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: What was your sense of the relative prospects of people? Did they all- did all types come in the library at that time?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: And as you got to know them gradually did you have a sense of what their future possibilities were, relative, one to the other?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: You know, I can remember David describing to me how he saw South Africa and he saw it as- there would be- the White people were at the front of the river and then there were the Colored people and then there were the Indian people and then the great big Black crocodile at the back, behind- In the river, if it was a river where you were going.

p.hi: Q: Through the eyes of the outsiders seeing this for the first time.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes.

p.hi: Q: Yes.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Because people were pushed away so that you didn't see the-

p.hi: Q: But you took the effort or you were asked to, to go to some of the townships, Guguletu and others. Does anything stand out from that five year period; any particular program? You mentioned the theater group that you gave a venue; did you do any international visitors or Fulbrighters?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No. You know, I didn't have anything to do with exchange programs then.

p.hi: Q: They all came through Pretoria, I suppose.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: They came through Pretoria, yes. And I didn't really understand. I knew that they were students and I've kept my records of people that I had and I knew that there were names of people that I knew came from Cape Town in the '60s who went on the Fulbright program, for instance.

p.hi: Q: That's fine.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: During the time that I was there, and I joined from '64, and then I recognized some of the names of people who would come in to the office; I'd see here a name, Richard Reeve, a famous person, yes, who went and did a Masters in literature at Columbia in 1965; people like that.

p.hi: Q: Fantastic. Where was Dennis Brutus from; was he from the Cape? Johannesburg perhaps.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I think Johannesburg; I think Johannesburg, yes.

p.hi: Q: And then you met a person named Jacot.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. But I met him the same year that I joined the embassy, 1964 was my year.

p.hi: Q: Because that's the name you now bear we have to spend a moment finding out what it was that took you from Cape Town to Pretoria.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: A wedding ring lured me to the land of the Voortrekker Monument. Indicating nothing else would have. When people used to come into the library and say we hear you're leaving, where are you go, I'd cry and say Pretoria, because Pretoria had such a reputation for conservatism and it deserved its reputation I found, when I got there.

p.hi: Q: So the wedding ring and I think the man who offered it were something of great worth, taking you to a place- you did not want to come to Pretoria.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No.

p.hi: Q: Did you know that before coming that you did not really want to?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I came to Pretoria for the first time when he had come to Pretoria and then invited me to visit him, which I did, and that was my first exposure. But I just wanted, you know, I wanted to be wed. Let's not go all into the wrinkles or anything.

p.hi: Q: It's up to you, actually; you're going to get to edit all of this.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Okay.

p.hi: Q: Okay so love and marriage triumphed over your sense of place, I guess. Do you remember the day you left Cape Town?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Well, I remember the little farewell party that they had for me and photographs and things. I had a lot of friend; I was very happy and I used to- I enjoyed- I had a couple of wonderful experiences when I was there. Bobby Kennedy came to South Africa.

p.hi: Q: UCT (University of Cape Town).

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: and to UCT. And we worked for him and I can remember going into the consul general's office and seeing his- Bobby's aides sitting with their feet up on the desks- I was appalled to see that.

p.hi: Q: Now, you must know this is too historic a moment for us to pass over lightly. You must help us remember the famous visit where he spoke at UCT.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: He spoke, yes, and we all went up and I can remember my teeny little car, I had Jacot's little gray Vauxhall and we couldn't get up- We followed the cavalcade and then it was just, there were so many- what seemed like thousands of people and probably was close to a thousand, outside in the grounds and we just parked in the middle of the road on the UTC campus and went up into the main hall.

p.hi: Q: So you heard the speech?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes, yes, I was there, yes.

p.hi: Q: Now tell, before we get to the speech, which is a historic moment, what was your involvement with the Robert Kennedy visit?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: We did some typing for them. It was the UTC visit and then they also went and visited the Simonsberg hostel, a hostel at Stellenbosch University.

p.hi: Q: Why did Robert Kennedy come? He was attorney general at that time?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: What was it, was it his personal interest? What brought him this great distance?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Oh gosh, I don't know.

p.hi: Q: Was it just part of being the Kennedy clan?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I think so. And the U.S. saying what they thought about academic freedom and that, because he delivered the academic freedom speech.

p.hi: Q: Yes. And I know it's, well 30 years, 35 years ago, what do you remember, not the quotes, but what do you remember of the gist of that speech? The text is readily available I think.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Just encouraging; I don't know that I really remember too much. I think I was so over overwhelmed by the whole occasion, you know, and just being there, part of it.

p.hi: Q: Can you describe what it was that was overwhelming? Was it him, was it the group?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: It was also him. Don't forget we were in the presence of the man who everybody thought would be the next president of the United States of America and that was an assumed experience.

p.hi: Q: This was '67?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Sixty-six, I think it was.

p.hi: Q: Sixty-six. And he lived until '68.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. And then we met- we got to meet him afterwards. There was a function at Hedding Hall and he and Mrs. Kennedy were there and he had all his aides and they came along and we got to shake his hand and he said give her a pin, give her a pin, and I still have the U-boat from JFK and that was- I've got that little pin.

p.hi: Q: Oh my, oh my. How many people were at that reception? That was a by invitation?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Oh hundreds.

p.hi: Q: But it was hundreds, yes.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, but we were all there as the workers.

p.hi: Q: Now, in the hall, at that time it was a white campus, I think. Is that correct?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes. But I think there were-

p.hi: Q: The audience was mixed?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Predominantly, predominantly white.

p.hi: Q: Now, okay, and then after his visit, I suppose you must have been busy providing photos and text to the local newspapers perhaps?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes we did.

p.hi: Q: Was it a big story the next day?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Oh huge, huge.

p.hi: Q: I mean, stupid question. Yes. And did it-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Banner headlines. And then I think we also- I'm trying to think what it was, there were headlines in the paper because he was in Waterkloof; he came to Pretoria after Cape Town, I think, and there were pictures of him walking around Waterkloof shaking hands with domestic workers and gardeners and that, you know.

p.hi: Q: So he made a point to-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: So he made a point of acknowledging the black citizens of South Africa, yes.

p.hi: Q: Did you have any sense of the regime at all stressed about this contact? Did they mind, did they care? Was there any sense of being observed or any sense of an attempt to control the venues?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, no, no, that doesn't mean to say that it didn't happen but that I can't remember specifically.

p.hi: Q: Right. It was done subtly perhaps, at times.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Well maybe not even so subtly because subtlety wasn't part of their vocabulary.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Well, let's get you to Pretoria. Nineteen-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Sixty-nine.

p.hi: Q: And did you immediately find yourself at the U.S. embassy?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No. Because the only job they offered me was in the budget and fiscal section and not being able to control my own checkbook I decided no, and I went and worked in commerce for two years. And in those days they didn't used to advertise; all appointments were made by sort of word of mouth.

p.hi: Q: This was the commerce section of the embassy or the ministry of commerce?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, no, just the embassy itself.

p.hi: Q: Oh yes.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: The embassy, the personnel section and I got a- I was really getting tired; it was a 20 mile trip each day, you know, there and back to the job that I had and they phoned and asked would I come back. And I came back and for two years I was the FSN (Foreign Service National) assistant to the admin consular and I had a very- didn't have nearly enough to do and I was complaining about that and after awhile they gave me- I would stand in when people were on vacation and it was very valuable. I did a stint in the general services and I got to appreciate what those good folk do. You know, we tend to complain about them but they had their schedule for the day and then the ambassador's wife phones because the loo's broken and they have to drop everything. So I did- I worked-

p.hi: Q: Well we complain when things go wrong but we never notice when things go right.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: When it goes right, no. I worked in personnel; it was very helpful, I worked in the general services travel section for awhile and I learned a lot, which was to stand me in very good stead when I eventually moved to USIS. I worked in budget and fiscal, all of them, and then, I remember the late Frank Strovis, he was there in those days working with the PAO (public affairs officer), was Perry L. Peterson.

p.hi: Q: Perry L.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, whom I'm still in touch with. And Frank was his IO, and Frank was dating Marcy McKee, who was the American secretary to the admin counselor and March and I were great friends, and Frank knew that I had had- I'd worked for USIS for five years and my predecessor in the exchange program, a wonderful woman, Mrs. Robbey, who'd been there for a million years, they discovered that she was 70; horror of horrors, you're not allowed to work a day over, I think, 65, and she- and so they wanted to replace her and I got the job because I had the previous-

p.hi: Q: There you were right there.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: -yes. And Obe Pitswana, Obe the driver and I joined USIS on the First of February 19- First of January, sorry, 1973.

p.hi: Q: Seventy-three. So it was four years-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Since I'd left-

p.hi: Q: Purgatory. Before finding yourself-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And from day one it was just wonderful.

p.hi: Q: We're going to, of course, get to that. I'm going to break the rule of chronology and ask- I should have asked if there's anything you want to point out about your family, your upbringing, your education back at Cape Town.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I don't think so. You know, I don't have a- I've got no tertiary qualification or anything. I grew up- I matriculated, I did a secretarial course afterwards at the Technicon and then I worked for a leading firm of jewelers where I did the secretarial work and checked in the jewelry repairs, etc., for two years, then I went to work for an attorney, and I enjoyed that very much. I was there for a year but then he decided to go into commerce and joined a company and that was when I then was unemployed, which was rather nice, Cape Town in February and not having to work and going to the beach, etc. I was only 20, don't forget, and then- No, no, no; I was 21. And then my girlfriend was dating a young political officer and they knew that there was a job break going in USIS, and she was a librarian but she didn't have secretarial skills and I had the secretarial skills which they said was more important than the library, I'd be able to learn about the library, so that's how I got- Ernie Colton was the BPAO who interviewed and employed me.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Okay, let's fast forward to coming in USIS in 1979.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Seventy-three.

p.hi: Q: Now, you said it was wonderful from day one.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes it was. Just the exchange program.

p.hi: Q: Can you remember the first day or the first weeks or the first month?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I remember my first mistake. I can remember- I had great respect for Mr. Peterson; he was very, very nice. There wasn't a cultural attach� at this stage; Jerry Prillaman was yet to come so there was just- there was me and there was the American secretary and there was the RPMAO, budget person. And there was Ghandi Chang, who was Mimi's brother-in-law and he was in the film library; he was also a very able photographer. And my mistake was the grant; the IV grantee was the late Stan Kweyama, who was with the Citrus Exchange. I got a phone call from Mr. Peterson one Saturday morning. I was going to the racing; there was a phone call to say oh, Gill, there's a cable in from Washington and we haven't said when Stan's arriving. And I hadn't, I hadn't sent an ETA cable. I said, oh Mr. Peterson, I'm so sorry; I don't want to get you into trouble. And I came rushing in and sent off the cable so that was very-

p.hi: Q: Rushing in?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Into the office on a Saturday.

p.hi: Q: At odd hours on a Saturday.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, I often rushed in on weekends.

p.hi: Q: Again, this was before the days of easy phone calls.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. And that was also long before the days of computers.

p.hi: Q: Yes, of course.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: It was an electric typewriter there.

p.hi: Q: Very state-of-the-art, yes. Well, that doesn't sound like a mortal sin.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I was quite conscientious.

p.hi: Q: Maybe venal but not mortal.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Quite conscientious in those days.

p.hi: Q: Okay, so you got Kweyama off on time, he went to the U.S. In those days it was 30- or 40-day trips, I think, international.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, they were six weeks. And it didn't matter if they took their spouses along.

p.hi: Q: Ah.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: They were allowed to take their spouses. And in fact in many ways they were encouraged to take their spouses, particularly for people who had- who were disadvantaged in that they didn't have big budgets and that to go abroad was a very expensive exercise and you might be able to find the money for one person, and why should one person in the family have this wonderful experience and not be able to share it with his life partner.

p.hi: Q: Later discouraged in the '80s and '90s.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Late '80s discouraged.

p.hi: Q: Discouraged because the Washington bureaucracy found that having a spouse distracted the visitor, I think.

div.p: I see you looking at a list-
JACOT GUILLARMOD: I'm looking at- these are some of the IVs I sent in that year.

p.hi: Q: Do any names leap off the page?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Oh yes, Sheena Duncan, national president of the Black Sash; Wilkie (inaudible), who's still a huge name promoting mathematics. He was the first- he was really the black expert in the field of mathematics, and you know from your experience here there's a shortage of qualified black- black and white mathematicians that got much worse.

p.hi: Q: And scientists.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Sam Motsuenyane, who was the head of NAFCOC (National African Federal Chamber of Commerce) and he was a lovely man; he brings back lots of happy memories for me because he used to come into the embassy, well, into USIS, and he didn't have an office or anything and if he- I would make phone calls for him for appointments and with a white- the people would hear a white voice answer, make the call and I'd phone and say please, can I speak to Mr. X, Y Zed and they'd put me through and then I'd hand over and say here's- He ultimately- he got an honorary doctorate; he is Dr. Motsuenyane so I sort of acted as a, that is, his-

p.hi: Q: You were the intermediary.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: He was a wonderful, wonderful man, yes.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Now, at what point did you meet these folks? Did you- In some cases were these people that you brought to the attention of your American colleagues or did they-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Occasionally but you know only after I'd been there for awhile. For the first time, if you read that document that I gave you, I give great credit to my colleagues in the embassy and that for spotting “comers,” to use an American expression, that they really- And so many people who you see- who are running South Africa today were the occupied- key positions in our country were identified when they were still ready to be junior staff.

p.hi: Q: What types of people were spotting these? Were they South Africans and Americans alike?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: But it was more, it was more the Americans because in the State Department there weren't too many FSNs in the political section and that.

p.hi: Q: So the political section people were out and seeing things?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: They were seeing things.

p.hi: Q: And they-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And they identified-

p.hi: Q: Maybe they had fewer reporting requirements than they do today, maybe?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I don't know but they certainly- And don't forget it was very different then. It was so easy to identify the good guys and the bad guys.

p.hi: Q: How was it easy?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Because any- All the government people were associated, for the most part, you know, you've got the exceptions and then you knew about them but for the most part the government people were associated and I became very anti-government; I became very intolerant, I think, of anybody who I thought didn't agree with me.

p.hi: Q: Yes. Now, but the embassy was sending some government visitors of course.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Oh yes, yes, because they didn't send only the people that they- who liked you; you also sent people you didn't like. I mean, before my time they sent Jimmy Krueger, that dreadful minister of justice who was the one who said that because death left him cold, and I think he went in about 1968.

p.hi: Q: So the American agenda was to try to reach every- to not be exclusive, to take people from the various sectors and if they misunderstood us or if we didn't like them, all the more reason for them to have some- if they were leaders-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Exposure.

p.hi: Q: -To have some exposure to the American system-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: They would send- don't forget, they sent a lot of media, they sent media folk. In the early days, if I go back and I look at my records of before I was involved with exchange program, the majority of people who went were white but gradually as the years went by the numbers-

p.hi: Q: And I gather from what you just said that your preference, your greater pleasure, was in sending those who did not have the established credentials of being in the government but who were thinking about the country's future. Now, the famous F. W. de Klerk visit-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, 1976.

p.hi: Q: Seventy-six.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: He was a member of parliament for Vereeniging in those days when he went.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Now, and in the famous quote he said, eight, seven or eight years later he said because of the trip to the U.S., something like I understand race relations; he said something like that.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes.

p.hi: Q: Do you remember, in '76, were you at all involved in processing this?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, he was from Johannesburg so I- I did the paperwork so it would have my letter- my signature at the bottom of the letter which would have gone sending off his air ticket and his travel allowance and telling him what to expect. But I didn't meet him personally; I really only- I would meet- I obviously met the people who came through the Pretoria office and I used to go to the airport almost without fail, I saw off almost every person of color who went on- In those days it was Pan Am flights twice a week and they went via Rio de Janeiro and beyond.

p.hi: Q: Now, why did you feel it was necessary or helpful to accompany people of color?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Because so many of the people that we sent had never flown, had never been out of the country and also to make quite sure that they didn't encounter any difficulties with checking in.

p.hi: Q: What types of difficulties might they have encountered at the airport? Documentation, exit visas and all that?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Perhaps; perhaps, yes. And also you wanted them to know that we really wished them well and that- it was nice.

p.hi: Q: Do you remember what you felt when you signed the de Klerk grant or invitation letter? Did any-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, he was no different than anybody else in that state.

p.hi: Q: He was just part of any other person in the government.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Who knew that he would be the person to release Nelson Mandela?

p.hi: Q: Did you, actually just on de Klerk on a moment, I mean, you must have met him in following decades, I guess.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes but only on about two occasions and I don't even think that they were thanks to-

p.hi: Q: To the U.S. program.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No.

p.hi: Q: It was just because you were-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: It happened at other things.

p.hi: Q: - or public events where he was present.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Things like that, yes.

p.hi: Q: Yes, okay. Pan Am; imagine.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Pan Am 202.

p.hi: Q: Pan Am 202. Which is what, Johannesburg-Cape Town-Rio, like that?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. But you didn't get off the plane in Cape Town.

p.hi: Q: So you would just stay in the plane for many centuries and end up somehow- And then from Rio-
Q: I mean, that's the closest geographic point in the Western Hemisphere to land in, I suppose, just about.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I think there was some- They didn't all go. Don't forget there would be a couple of years when you'd have a particular route and then there were others when they went round through West Africa and across to Washington.

p.hi: Q: Right. There was the Dakar-New York Pan Am flight.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And you had to fly American carrier, regardless. It didn't matter if you could get a British Airways at half the price.

p.hi: Q: That's still the case. I know because here I am in Pretoria and, same thing.

div.p: So, do you have any- What would be your guess as to how many people per year benefited from the International Visitors Program in the '70s, '80s in South Africa? I mean, you had to sign the letter. Would it be 15 or 20?
JACOT GUILLARMOD: I would do the- No, many more than that; about 35.

p.hi: Q: Thirty-five.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And there were partials, too. It was before, really before the volvis [Voluntary Visitors] program grew and what- in those days we called it FSV, facilitated assistance.

p.hi: Q: Okay. We'll, just explain the voluntary visitors program very briefly, which is a program which-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: With somebody who is going to the United States but they would have the same characteristics of an IV so that if they weren't going you might nominate them and they would be there and you would set up appointments for them with counterparts in their field. And occasionally- Now they also give them- even when I was leaving they were giving funding but initially they would set up just the appointments and there was no money entailed.

p.hi: Q: Facilitated assistance.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Facilitated assistance.

p.hi: Q: And the programs can be as short as one week, I think.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: So 35 visitors per year; did you notice the gradual shift in demographics from '79 to the '80s and the '90s?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: For which program?

p.hi: Q: International Visitors and for Facilitated Assistance.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: It was an unwritten rule that it had to be two-thirds black.

p.hi: Q: Ah. Whose rule? The U.S.?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I don't know; I don't know.

p.hi: Q: Ah, interesting.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: But I know I- It was just- That was when they had the IV selection meeting; they- that's what they did. The list of finalists that came out-

p.hi: Q: When we say- black in the American sense, which would include colored and Asian?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Oh very definitely yes, yes. I think that was during the Carter Administration that we started using a policy of two-thirds black although this was an unwritten law.

p.hi: Q: Did you find, in the '70s, you started in '73, did you sense a directive coming from Washington or from your American colleagues in country here, what was the objective of U.S. policy from your- What do you guess? A gradual change or status quo or we're here to make commercial, to benefit commercially; do you think it was a mixture? Was there a consistent policy?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I think to show South Africans that they were- there was a better way to do things, to show that democracy worked.

p.hi: Q: Okay.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And then I think also, depending on who the officer was, some of them were more, you know, were more proactive; somebody like Jerry Prillaman.

p.hi: Q: Prillaman, yes, who was what, CAO (cultural affairs officer)?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: He was CAO, yes, from 1973 to about early '75. I've got something from him; I can look that up.

p.hi: Q: Yes. Later he was in-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: He went to Yaound� also.

p.hi: Q: He went to Yaound�, that's right. So Jerry stands out-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And then he was in Paris.

p.hi: Q: As one of the more active-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I actually saw him- I had lunch with him in Paris a little while ago.

p.hi: Q: I was in touch with him by email a few weeks ago.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Did you? About these things? Oh good. Because remember I had suggested to you that you contact both him and Brooks Specter.

p.hi: Q: Yes, but serendipitously I received a note from him- Maybe it did come from you but I received a note from him related to something else, I think. Anyway, I did have the honor of working with him.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Because his memory- and he had kept lots of notes.

p.hi: Q: Yes.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: It would be very valuable for this exercise.

p.hi: Q: Excellent. I'll try to do that. He lives in Paris I think.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, just outside of Paris. I've got his email address.

p.hi: Q: Yes, yes, please. I have it somewhere.

div.p: Okay, so things began to change and should be talk about Operation Crossroads Africa? At what point did it begin? I don't want to skip-
JACOT GUILLARMOD: That was, I think, 1974.

p.hi: Q: Seventy-four, okay.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I think about '74.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Tell me, and tell the listener, the role of OCA, Operation Crossroads Africa, in the-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: OCA was the only racial program that we presented.

p.hi: Q: What do you mean by that?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: It did not- it was not possible for a white person to go on an OCA program but it all- people of all other colors could go.

p.hi: Q: We have to mention Bart Russeve, our late friend from New Orleans, who administered these programs, who came here every year recruiting-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: He started- and at 73, I'm sorry; he sent for Franklin Sonn, who ended up being- who was the-

p.hi: Q: Franklin Sonn, later ambassador.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: To the United States, he was in the first-

p.hi: Q: The first real ambassador, I think you could say.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Was he an IV?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, he was OCA.

p.hi: Q: OCA?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. In 1973. There were four people who went that year.

p.hi: Q: Well gee whiz. Did you know Franklin Sonn?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No.

p.hi: Q: No. But you-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: He came from Cape Town but Frank Sassman knew him.

p.hi: Q: Yes, yes, yes. Frank Sassman knew him.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Wow.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: He was the principle of the Peninsula Technicon in those days.

p.hi: Q: The Pen- yes, Peninsula Technicon. And then the first ambassador under the Mandela- under the new regime, I think.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, I think so.

p.hi: Q: I think so, I think so. Ninety-four.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Ninety-four, yes.

p.hi: Q: Well, there's evidence of-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: An effective list. But we- If you and I had 30 hours we could go through here and come up with hundreds of evidence of the victims.

p.hi: Q: I have 30 hours; maybe you don't.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Ridiculous.

p.hi: Q: That's what it said. Tell me about what you remember of Bart Rousseve and his visits here.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I just worshipped the ground he walked on. After he'd been here for a few years, it was just wonderful; he always used to let me have a party for him when he was visiting and I always got 100 percent acceptance for that because everybody would just come for Bart.

p.hi: Q: He came once a year, I think.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: He came once a year, yes. A shame, you know, even then, I realize now when, you know, after he died, that he had, what's it called? There's an illness call necropsy.

p.hi: Q: Narcolepsy.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Narcolepsy.

p.hi: Q: That's exactly-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And he clearly had that because I used to sit him on interviews- after awhile I began- The first several years I didn't, wasn't part of the interviewing process and then I got to be asked and it was lovely and I did that; I did it with- I ended up doing it with Fulbright, I did it with OCA and I used to do the, for IVs I used to do the program suggestions, he met with the grantees.

p.hi: Q: And the narcolepsy?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And Bart would nod off in interviews and I would, you know, take over.

p.hi: Q: So it would be you and Bart plus the candidate?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And always-

p.hi: Q: An officer.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Another, an officer.

p.hi: Q: An officer, whether Jerry Prillaman or somebody like that.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes. And sometimes an alumnus.

p.hi: Q: Again, let's get this away from you and the subject is you but we should mention that Bart died in a car accident when he was driving at night on the Taconic Freeway in New York State, and we think he fell asleep; he was driving to Boston.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. Because he'd been to a farewell party that they were having for him before he went off to- he was going to join the cloth.

p.hi: Q: Yes, 1994, 1994, the year that Mandela became president, yes.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And he was- when he left OCA he went to work for the IIE (Institute of International Education).

p.hi: Q: Yes.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And he worked in the South African-
Q; International Institute of Education, yes.
JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes. Based in New York.

p.hi: Q: Yes. And also for African American Institute at some point; AFGRAD (The African Graduate Fellowship Program) something.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: AFGRAD, yes.

p.hi: Q: So he kept coming kept coming here; he changed his position in the States but he kept coming here and working with you as he changed from one organization to the next.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. And he was very kind because he used to say to me, oh Gill, what can I do to repay you? And I said, in 1988 I said, there's something you can do. I had a whole lot of South Africans studying in New York at that stage and he let me cook them a meal in his apartment on 121st Street in Harlem, and I walked from 42nd Street to 121st Street and then I went and did shopping, cooking and they all came along. It was a most marvelous evening.

p.hi: Q: So you cooked a meal for South African visitors in Bart's home.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: A chicken dinner in Bart's home, yes. And many of those, the Fulbrighters and the OCAs and the AFGRADs, then all became friends also; people met who hadn't met other than that. So Bart was such a catalyst in bringing people together.

p.hi: Q: Yes. They also met other Africans from other countries in the continent.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: And I was eyewitness to a number of times when the South Africans were greeted with suspicion from the other participants.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I experienced it myself.

p.hi: Q. Gill, tell us what you remember of the difficulty in integrating black South African participants into African programs in the U.S.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Oh no, I didn't mean it that way; I meant that when I went on my FSN orientation program in 1979 I was on the same program as Deva and Ron Hendrickse and it was for all cultural assistants across Africa. They were a group of about 30 and I was the only white and the rest made it very difficult for Deva and Ron because the rest of the group were very unhappy that I was there.

p.hi: Q: Why?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Because I was white.

p.hi: Q: It may seem obvious but-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, because I was white. I mean, the guy from Kano, Nigeria, big, big man, said if my government had known you were going to be here I wouldn't have been allowed to come. And the lady from Liberia, with her Diane von Furstenberg luggage, said to me, tell me- Ron and I had been in Miami for three days beforehand and I'd had my hair permed and curly and I'd been in the sun so I was quite brown, probably browner than Ron, and she asked me was I classified colored, and I said I was very sorry to tell her but I was classified white. And so they really resented me at first but by the end of the trip they were quite good about saying, oh- the same Kano man patted me on my head and told me I was a good woman. And Gilbert from Togo said he was going to take me home to be his South African souvenir.

p.hi: Q: Well, let's give Gill Jacot Guillarmod some credit for making people feel at ease. This is something that you've always done supremely well.

div.p: Deva, Ron and you, I had no idea you went to-
JACOT GUILLARMOD: The same-

p.hi: Q: - you had known of them and you had worked with Ron?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Oh, had worked with them both, no: closely.

p.hi: Q: So this was not a new relationship?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, no, no, no.

p.hi: Q: Well, let me just add that with IVs, which I did deal with at that time, black South African IVs were met with extreme suspicion.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Because their people thought that they were sellouts.

p.hi: Q: Exactly.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, that was true.

p.hi: Q: Or spies or what have you and they had to prove at a very early stage that they were not in order for there even to be the possibility- It was quite tense, quite tense.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I know that, and I'll tell you this, let me tell you another little issue. There was a time during the Carter era that the South African government introduced the homeland situation, Bophuthatswana and KwaZulu, etc. And then they would enforce, nine times out of ten, they would insist that anybody, if we invited them- I have to- No. Let me back track also.
I have to tell you that, and I found that quite interesting when I listened to my counterparts in other countries; the South African government never dictated to us who we had to invite.

p.hi: Q: Very important.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Unlike in many of the other countries where you had to go through the ministry of this, that and the other, and there was quite a bit of nepotism in that, this is what I heard from my own colleagues over there, the South African government never did but on the other hand they had control by denying an invitee a passport, so that was the way. Then, when the homeland came into being they insisted that people travel on homeland passports and many- several blacks refused to travel on these dummy passports while there were others and let me, if I can quote you one, Sej Motau, who coincidentally is now standing as a DA (Democratic Alliance) candidate in Pretoria—I can't believe it. He went on OCA and he also went and did a Masters in journalism at Berkeley. He was a senior journalist on the “Pretoria News” and he occupied big positions with DeBeers in Canada and London; everything. He was the- But when we invited him for the first time on OCA he was told that he could only have homelands, Bophuthatswana passport.

p.hi: Q: Which was not recognized anywhere outside South Africa.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Nowhere else in the world, no, no.

p.hi: Q: So he could not have arrived- He could not have been admitted into the U.S.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: But we gave- we would give special, a special document that the consulate general would then stamp so that the person could get in.

p.hi: Q: A travel permit.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: A travel permit, yes. Sej said I know what I am. I'm not going to be deprived of a trip- of realizing a dream by somebody giving me a fake document. I will accept it to go and he went.

p.hi: Q: So others did refuse.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: A few did. Some said no, that they wouldn't travel on it.

p.hi: Q: It's their loss, perhaps.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I would think that it was. I did find, also, that many people who'd been very vehement and said oh, they'd never go to the land of the imperialists, that once they actually had an invitation in their hand they were able to come to terms with the decision.

p.hi: Q: The body language does not go on the tape. Implying, what? A certain openness or opportunism or-?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: But I think, but whatever it is, who would blame them? No, no, no.

p.hi: Q: A marvelous offer.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: So it's covering- What's it doing to your principles but so what? No, so what? Because don't forget we send people over, the languages for the mutual exchange of ideas and that, so they were going to influence Americans and Americans were going to influence them.

p.hi: Q: You mention a phrase which to me is a very potent and emotional one, mutual understanding, which is a phrase used in the Fulbright Hayes Act of 1948-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And which was always part of the letter of invitation.

p.hi: Q: Always part. And injecting myself just for a second, I think that this mutual understanding aspect has taken a secondary place in our exchanges. Share with us your feeling of the importance of mutual. I mean, it's a leading question because I'm in favor of it and now that we're sending text messages out and all forms of electronic communication for which there's no real face to face feedback, do you have any reflections on this notion of mutual understanding? Because it's important to me I'm asking you.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I used to think also that America was so vast a place, with every kind of opportunity there and every conviction, that you could send people, and I mentioned earlier we didn't only send those who liked us; we also sent those who didn't, people like Adrian FlVak and Jimmy Krueger but if a person had a really narrow mind there was enough going on in America that was disappointing that they would find it and if they wanted to they could come back saying oh, you see, it's exactly the same over there. But most times, I think, that people's persuasions were changed. I really do think. If not immediately but I think that it impacted on people, that they were able to see that there was a different way to do this.

p.hi: Q: I guess it was never codified or a particular policy but I know the U.S. Government tried to show everything and not to conceal anything while visitors were in the U.S., hoping for the best. And as you say some people had their prejudices and their stereotypes confirmed, others found some surprises. Would you recommend this to any large country, to have unfettered access? Again, I ask a leading question.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. Yes, absolutely.

p.hi: Q: Okay now, you were going to tell me about the homelands act. Oh you did; no, you did. That is the government insisting on-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: The people having- on people traveling-

p.hi: Q: -the homelands coming on these passports that were not recognized.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And it would say citizenship un- You know, it also would say citizenship undetermined.

p.hi: Q: A passport?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: A passport.

p.hi: Q: I don't get it. How can you have a passport without a citizenship?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, it would be stated but undetermined.

p.hi: Q: Amazing. Okay, so the U.S. embassy found a way of issuing a travel document that allowed people with these useless passports nevertheless to be recognized by the INS (Immigration and Naturalization Service).

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: But then of course they could only go to the United States, so that they couldn't-

p.hi: Q: No multiple entry.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And they couldn't go as- when there wasn't an American carrier people could go by London. There were times when there wasn't a Pan Am, you could go somewhere- They couldn't, they really had to- But what they could do, occasionally, was to just go and stay in-

p.hi: Q: Transit.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: In transit, in transit.

p.hi: Q: So they could go through London but they could not go to London.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, they couldn't go to London. And of course people- For a while we worked with the British embassy if somebody was going- Jerry was very good about this; if he saw- read an article in the paper that somebody was going to the UK or-

p.hi: Q: Jerry Vogel?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Jerry Prillaman.

p.hi: Q: Jerry Prillaman.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: We would write to them and I continued doing that; if we read about anybody I'd write and say, you know, from time to time we have exchange programs and would you be prepared to give me your bio data.

p.hi: Q: Yes, the UK was cooperative?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes. We'd occasionally- They would pay for them to go to a round trip to London and we'd pay from London to the United States.

p.hi: Q: Really? Really?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Not often but a few times.

p.hi: Q: Sometimes.

div.p: Now, we've talked about OCA, we've talked about International Visitors, writ large; we haven't talked about Fulbright yet.
JACOT GUILLARMOD: No. Let's stick onto short-term ones so let's do the CIP.

p.hi: Q: The Cleveland International Program.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, for youth leaders and social workers.

p.hi: Q: Yes. Again, the late CIP. But, your recollections of CIP.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Oh, just phenomenal, phenomenal. And people would go for four months. They were all social workers initially; they'd go for four months, they lived with American host families and they worked under the guidance of a mentor. And it was phenomenal and I can remember-

p.hi: Q: This is like internship sort of.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, it was an intern but a practical hands on experience. And I can remember in 1975 we had a CIP- I'm trying to think, Dr., the name of the man who- Oh, who can I forget? Who was CIP for many, many years. Ollendorff? I think that was his name.

p.hi: Q: Yes. Yes, yes, yes. Henry Ollendorff.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Henry Ollendorff. And Henry came out to South Africa and we had a workshop and in- at the Boulevard Hotel, and I had to get special ministerial permission for black people to stay at the Boulevard- It wasn't an international hotel but we still had to get special permission for black people to stay in the hotel and that's where we had- they were accommodated there and we had-

p.hi: Q: In Pretoria.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: -the workshop in Pretoria, yes.

p.hi: Q: Was your own race, did it make it easier for you to get such permission?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, it was the embassy.

p.hi: Q: Ah, ah. Okay, okay.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: That opened many doors if I started a conversation with, hello, I'm Gill Jacot Guillarmod from the American embassy.

p.hi: Q: Yes. Now, so you mentioned this visit of Henry Ollendorff.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: What was the occasion?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: To, I think, because CIP had been in existence for quite awhile and they wanted to have- It could have been the tenth anniversary or something that we had it.

p.hi: Q: Now, you said phenomenal, wonderful; four month internships, host families.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And I think why it was so amazing was because in those days, particularly I'm talking about the black social worker, they weren't just social workers; they were every single- they occupied every single position in the townships that they could. They were fundraisers; they were guidance counselors; they were parents in- what's that expression?

p.hi: Q: Mentors. In loco parentis.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: In loco parentis. Yes. They really- And their doors were open 24 hours a day to people and so that was wonderful, to be able to give people like that an opportunity to go and- Because they were trained at Fort Hare; that's where the only sort of black school of social work was.

p.hi: Q: Yes. Now, on selection, did they send out people the way OCA did or did you select them? The people-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, we would select them.

p.hi: Q: Fort Hare, Eastern Cape, right?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Fort Hare, on the Eastern Cape.

p.hi: Q: Easter Cape.

div.p: Okay. Again, I don't know if it's all that important to remember the individual names but generically what's your sense of how this transformed people, to go off from a township, be in a city in the U.S. for months and to come back.

JACOT GUILLARMOD: I was able to- that's one of the reasons that the job was so meaningful to me, because I was able to witness people return with a greater sense of their own self worth. And I can remember after an OCA- a woman who went on the OCA program, we had- there was a lady by the name of Dorothy, she was the counsel, chairperson of the African- the American Council of Negro Women, I think. Dorothy something. And we had, in our funny little- this is when the embassy was still downtown, not in its great big luxury building now, we had a multipurpose room, which had all sorts of wonderful things there. But we had a group of women come together, talking, and Miss Dorothy was the keynote address and she was, to be honest she was no great shakes but she was the most marvelous catalyst at bringing all these women together.

p.hi: Q: This was an American who had traveled-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: An African American woman who came, she was our guest-

p.hi: Q: As a speaker.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. Because don't forget, I didn't do only the outgoing exchanges, I did all the incoming exchanges as well, in those days, which is wonderful because I could get the two to mesh together. You'd meet somebody and then send them on exchange program then you could program with them again when they came back; it worked so well. But I can remember that particular day, and I can't think what the topic was that she spoke about and- but I can remember an African woman getting up and a white woman had spoken in a rather patronizing way and the black woman got up and said, you know, don't you tell me that. And she just spoke- and I was so proud of her, she was just really-

p.hi: Q: This was, you think, partly because of her trip to the U.S.?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I'm pretty sure. I mean, it happened just two months afterwards. I don't think she would have had the, well, not the courage but-

p.hi: Q: The gumption.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, gumption, probably a good word, you know, to have done. So yes, we certainly did see people come back-

p.hi: Q: So what you remember of the value of CIP was it increased people's self confidence.
Q: Very important. So that's something you could say generically for all the exchanges.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Absolutely, absolutely, yes.

p.hi: Q: Before we go to Fulbrights, other comments, other recollections of the short-term visits? There were Humphreys-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Well, don't forget, you know, CIP closed and then we had another- we had the Indiana- the South African internship program but that was- I don't know what period you're covering.

p.hi: Q: The whole thing.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: What, up until I left?

p.hi: Q: I remember when CIP was put to rest; it would have been in '93 or '94 and bureaucrats- because I was there at that time- bureaucrats- the comment was we've supported them all of this years, let's give someone else a chance. That was the argument; I was in the room. A truly idiotic decision.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And how. And how, because they did wonderful work. I happened to be at a CIP conference in Cleveland and I was flying from Cleveland to San Francisco when P.W. Botha made his Cross the Rubicon speech and the South African exchange rate, the rand plummeted, never to return.

p.hi: Q: Please explain this speech, “Cross the Rubicon.”
Q: And you were in the U.S. at that time.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I was in the U.S., yes. With all the CIP grantees who happened to be there. It was '85 and I was on the senior FSN program that I went- I was based in Washington for three months.

p.hi: Q: So did it feel as if on a micro level things were advancing very nicely partly because of your programs and on the macro level it sounds as if you were frustrated with the slow-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Very, yes, very frustrated. Because strange things were happening. Because, I mean, during that time also they changed the laws about the group areas act, the passports. And I can remember seeing Sheena Duncan, whom I mentioned earlier, who was the head of the Black Sash, I can remember seeing her being interviewed on CNN and her eyes just filled with tears. She said well if it is true it's the most marvelous news. And it was true.

p.hi: Q: Sorry; if what was true?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: If it was true that people were no longer going to have to- the group areas-

p.hi: Q: Abide by the group areas act.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes.

p.hi: Q: Okay.

div.p: Some of the readers of this are not familiar with Black Sash. Could you explain Black Sash?

JACOT GUILLARMOD: It was an organization founded by a bunch of women at the time when the South African government was about to remove the colored, the so-called colored people from the voter's roll and these women got up to protest and they formed the group and they stood- they chained themselves to the fences of the houses of parliament and they wore a black sash to show this sort of, this in mourning sign and that's how they got their name. And then they continued; they had branches around the country and they had advice officers, where people would- their members would volunteer their services and people would come in and it was usually for areas, things like people having been evicted because they weren't a with pass for the Group Areas Act.

p.hi: Q: Now, I think, my understanding is that members of Black Sash had a certain social prestige because of who they were. I think. Or was it people of all the groups?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I just think that you- black people, the black people were perhaps a little- appreciative of what the Black Sash were trying to do.

p.hi: Q: Was Helen Suzman at all connected with- she was a member of parliament at that time?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I don't- She was a member of parliament in the Cape. No, I don't ever remember Helen as being- because I was a member of Black Sash in Pretoria.

p.hi: Q: You say they chained themselves in Cape Town.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, to parliament one day.

p.hi: Q: Do you remember which- what did people do in Pretoria in Black Sash?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: We did quite a few things. We would- when, in '87 when they banned all the- “The Mail” and “Guardian” and the other newspapers and that, we held demonstrations in the streets and that. But the most helpful thing that we did, I think was, running this advice office, where we would take and then we would get lawyers to work pro bono and assist people.

p.hi: Q: Now this obviously was extracurricular to your position at the embassy.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Was there ever any question about your doing both things at the same time? Did anybody ever-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: What, by the embassy?

p.hi: Q: Yes.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No.

p.hi: Q: No. The embassy was just fine, just fine.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No. Didn't mind, no.

p.hi: Q: Because the embassy, I think, was dealing with laws and practices that the embassy did not agree with. For example, refusing to get the passes that would allow them into the black market.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes.

p.hi: Q: So there was a certain confrontation but they had to be following some of the rules, I suppose.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Well, we're still talking about CIP here and you were mentioning, off line, there was an individual who sort of became the unofficial South African representative.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes, a Mrs. Mary Uys. She went in '62; she's gone to heaven a long time ago. And in initial years there were two, three, four people a year. When I started off in '73 there were five that year and then five and four and then they started, every now and again there would be extra- we'd get extra money for a special program and the numbers would then be increased.

p.hi: Q: Now, what, Gill, explain how, in a country of, what, 40 million or something like that?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, now, yes.

p.hi: Q: We're talking about five per year.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Tell me, how can you change a society with five people?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Each little drop; each person has a multiplier affect and each person reaches somebody else and goes on with the group and they're an inspiration to the people in the community with them.

p.hi: Q: Did you find that some of the visitors, or most of them in turn, aside from their personal and family connections, did they make public appearances that may have alluded to their visits directly or indirectly?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Very often they would- most people would give great credit to their American experience. And you'd get some who didn't want to share, who didn't want to- another companion. Don't forget, people who have been deprived of so much for so long are going to also want to keep things to themselves so they perhaps wouldn't be so good about recommending other able candidates.

p.hi: Q: A certain jealousy, yes?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. But that's, you know, that's-

p.hi: Q: That's not South African; that's human.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: That's worldwide.

p.hi: Q: That's human, yes, that's human. Okay, but whereas Mary Uys was active or- was she self-selected? Did she- after her experience-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I don't know; that was in '62.

p.hi: Q: That would be before, before you were there.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: It was all before my, yes.

p.hi: Q: But she was known to you as a CIP alumna who was helpful in finding other candidates.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. Yes, yes, yes.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Now, did CIP candidates come from the various provinces? Did they tend to be from one-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: From all over. And they were all races. As I said, OCA was the only program which was restricted to people of color.

p.hi: Q: Okay. In its final days OCA did have white South Africans; very few, very few.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I don't know that I ever met-

p.hi: Q: I met some actually.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. No, no, no, no, you are right.

p.hi: Q: The point is that CIP-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: No, you are right. In, just in the last couple of years.

p.hi: Q: But CIP did not have this policy and they welcomed everybody.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Again, before going to Fulbright, other recollections of the individual program- well, and group, group program, because sometimes you would send small groups that would be- become part of larger groups, the single country programs, you would collect three, four, five, six South Africans, send them together perhaps.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. I think something that's important to say is when I was first started being involved with the IV program, just about everybody went on an individual grant and South Africans weren't sent on group, multi regional group projects or regional group projects because having a South African in the group, no matter what his or her color was, was like a lightening rod and the whole group would then only want to talk about what was happening in South Africa. And I think they found it disruptive and they didn't- and gradually they started to go more and more into group projects until now I think the majority probably are on group program- even in my last years.

p.hi: Q: I think so.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Because it was also, I mean, it was- on a group program you've got access- a high powered person is far more likely to make him or herself available for an hour or two to meet with a group of 10 or five or 20 than they are for just one little individual.

p.hi: Q: Groups will get to see Sandra Day O'Connor; individuals may not.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: That's from my own experience.

div.p: Okay, so until the social change took place in South Africa it was just difficult for many reasons and to mix any type of South Africans-

JACOT GUILLARMOD: I mean, they did go; they did go on group programs but really- And we also then would occasionally have single country projects but for the most part people were on individual programs.
JACOT GUILLARMOD: Gender; maybe some gender issues.

p.hi: Q: Gender. Are we now into the '80s here?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Into the '80s, yes. But I mean, you had asked me about numbers; if you look-

p.hi: Q: Okay. So just taking your- maybe at random, 1988-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Going to looking at my records and that, in 1988 there were 47 people went on the IV program and those numbers there, 1989, large, the budget was very, very large.

p.hi: Q: Yes. Did you think that South Africa got an increased share of IVs because of its special circumstances?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, I think also- I think we were quite on the ball. We would always send a number of alternates and then towards the end of the year, when other posts hadn't used up their funds, we had the people there already, the application was in, the person was able to go.

p.hi: Q: So some of your 47 was by dint of your own cleverness?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, I think probably.

p.hi: Q: Some of them were allocated, yes, yes.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And the same happened to the Fulbright.

p.hi: Q: Yes. Ready to shift to Fulbright?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Okay. And if you aren't- I don't know if you want to go to the '90s, when after-

p.hi: Q: Yes, oh yes.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Because, I mean, that was a hugely important part-

p.hi: Q: Especially when AID assisted in paying for some of these, yes.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes. We once got, going with AID money, it was all secret; we weren't allowed to know that the money came from AID but I think it was about in 1978 was the only time we had an undergraduate program and we sent undergrad students, about 18 of them, to get bachelor degrees-

p.hi: Q: You weren't allowed to know that AID-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: We didn't want anybody to know that it was- We didn't want the South African government to know that it was- that AID money was being spent in South Africa.

p.hi: Q: What difference would it be to-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: This was in 1978. Don't forget AID wasn't-

p.hi: Q: But it's the U.S. Government. To the South African government what difference would it make if it's the embassy or AID?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I don't know; they just called it CU/AF. I just remembered that.

p.hi: Q: Yes. The bureau-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I mean, I wasn't- didn't have access to classified material and things like that, so.

p.hi: Q: Yes. Okay. So the idea was that the South African government would not have been comfortable having USAID money spent without going through the government or something like that.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Perhaps, perhaps. I'm not sure.

p.hi: Q: Which is a problem- which is a factor in every country, overseas aid. The government always wants it and AID sometimes does and sometimes does not-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Want to work with-

p.hi: Q: -agree to go through the government; in this case not, I suppose.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: But what I was going to say was after the South African government- after, you know, Mandela was released, etc., the United States Government threw money at us and we had all sorts of money and all sorts of different categories. DES [Dire Emergency Supplemental]; I loved that.

p.hi: Q: Dire emergency.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Dire Emergency Supplemental, yes. That enabled us to send people for short periods, countless people who today hold very senior government positions.

p.hi: Q: This is AID funded, I think.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Well, I don't know. You know, for me it just came from Washington, yes. And that was followed by COLD.

p.hi: Q: Sorry; starting in 1992, when he was released? Or thereabouts?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Roundabout there, yes. Let me, if I just look and see- Ninety-two.

p.hi: Q: Okay.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Ninety-two; '92 we sent- started sending people with dire- DES.

p.hi: Q: Dire emergency. And then we should explain, I think, they called it “dire emergency” because the situation was changing so rapidly and the idea was not to avoid catastrophe but to benefit from the changes. Urgency they might have called it, rather than emergency.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Emergency, yes.

p.hi: Q: Maybe, maybe. But-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: That was followed by COLD.

p.hi: Q: COLD.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: COLD. Community Outreach and Leadership Development.

p.hi: Q: Similar money for similar purpose.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. Yes, yes, yes. Also helping to address the imbalance and level the playing fields for historically disadvantaged.

p.hi: Q: Right. And between- By the way, between '92 and '94, was there any question that there would be a major political change? Was it a given that the change was coming?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. But don't forget there was a lot of violence and that going on as well.

p.hi: Q: Potentially much more.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: More unexpected.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And things also with people, Mandela sort of clashing with de Klerk.

p.hi: Q: Yes. So that must have been a very important period, '92 to '94.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. And of the people that, you know, we sent-

p.hi: Q: And this was the time when these dire emergency, COLD-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: And then followed by the TSF, Transitional Support Fund.

p.hi: Q: Yes. So they changed the name of it but the gist of it was similar; it was to accelerate the exposure of the future leaders to the United States.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. And they all- they sent people, well we sent people in all different groups. We sent people from the Institute for Multi Party Democracy; there'd be a group from there. We'd send people from [inaudible, Safety and Security provincial legislature group. We sent a group that- of eight military folk, four from the South African, four from the South African military and four from the MK [military wing of the ANC.]

p.hi: Q: Now, this was a very dramatic event. I was present at the debriefing of this group.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Oh, okay.

p.hi: Q: It was Bob LaGamma's idea.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: It was Jerry Kenner, and who was the econ officer who subsequently became ambassador? Don Steinberg. He was a driving force with that.

p.hi: Q: Really?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Now, that was dramatic because it was very risky. You had people in the same room and sharing at a period where the outcome was unknown-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Who had guns against one another.

p.hi: Q: Spending their efforts trying to kill each other.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: So this was conflict resolution, enormous conflict resolution. What was your recollection of the- selecting that group, the- Did you sense any risk in putting these people together? Was their any apprehension? These were enemies trying to kill each other, put in the same group.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: But I think, no, me, I always think everything is going to turn out right, so I wouldn't have been-

p.hi: Q: And it did.
Q: What's the group in Durbin?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: ACCORD.

p.hi: Q: ACCORD.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: But now that- Accord was founded- one of my Fulbrighters was the founder of ACCORD and he came back. He went in about '85, I think.

p.hi: Q: Wow.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Vasu Gounden.

p.hi: Q: Vasu Gounden. I remember the name. I remember; yes, yes, yes.

div.p: So he was a Fulbrighter.
JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: And then he created ACCORD, the main conflict resolution NGO, not only for this country but for this part of the world.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, yes. I have a wonderful Washington, DC red tee shirt that he brought me.

p.hi: Q: And speaking of DC, you've mentioned a couple of trips. You went on two FSN training trips.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. In '79 and '85. And I went often on my own.

p.hi: Q: Yes.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: I've been to the States 11 times.

p.hi: Q: And when you went on your own you went to see friends; you went to see- And I think you would sometimes see some of your Fulbright grantees or-

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: They got- my bosses were very kind; on two occasions they gave me money to have luncheons in New York. On two occasions- times when there were a lot of students and they came from far and wide, the students. You may have about 20 odd coming for lunch and brunch; one time was brunch and one time was lunch. It was wonderful.

p.hi: Q: These would usually be Fulbrighters, I guess.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: They were Fulbrighters, yes.

p.hi: Q: Okay. Because those were the ones who would stay for awhile.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: Most Fulbrighters went for one or two years I think?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: One if they were doing an LLM or if they were doing a one year non-degree program but for most of them, the majority were actually two year programs.

p.hi: Q: Did you do Humphreys from here?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Did all the Humphrey, yes.

p.hi: Q: Yes, yes. And did some of them go to New York also?

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes.

p.hi: Q: You just happened to be- In New York there just happened to be a concentration.

div.p: JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes. Quite a few would go to- Humphrey was big. And I spent time with the people in Humphrey and-
Q; Now, this you did on your private time?
JACOT GUILLARMOD: Yes, but it was such a joy, you know.

p.hi: Q: Yes, yes. These were people you had assisted in doing their trips to the U.S. and then seeing-
